24. What hazards or difficulties did you experience? You might give details such as dates, severity, damage, methods of control, with respect to the following: hail, frost, wind and dust, blizzards, floods, drought, prairie fires, rust, smut, grasshoppers, cutworms, sawflies, caterpillars, mosquitoes, hawks, gophers, coyotes.

1911 heavy frost here & inch of ice three nights crop badly frozen did not get it all through till spring 1912 tough and damp after drying got 30¢ per bucket would have been better to have burnt it. In 1916 bad hail storm about Aug 5th or 6th all hailed out, only need 40 per cent instead of 100¢ from Municipal hail insurance of Regina never suffered any more worse Hailstorm I have seen not sound but slugs 2 to 3 inches long suffered also from dust part of crop blown out in 1930, and 33 and 1937, breeks no crop suffered some from sawfly and Hoppers

25. What weeds were present in your district when you first arrived and which were most common?

Stink weed came in from seed a neighbor had bought. Had to pull it and burn it, not spraying them day, me and wife spent hours at night pulling.

26. What new varieties of seeds appeared after you settled? (Give date of appearance if possible).

Lamb's quarter, mushing, thistle, tumbleweed, mustard, wild oats, shepherd's purse.

27. What method of harvesting and threshing grain did you first use?

By binder and had crops threshed by neighbor steam outfit.

For any new ones required in these operations? Cutting by hand myself at first, then used a binder.

1904 wheat hauled to Saskatoon with own team and after 1904 horses.

Forty-five miles, seven miles, nine miles.
